title: 115_hr4090
content: The Act is titled the "Fentanyl and Heroin Task Force Act" and establishes a task force to address fentanyl and heroin issues under the Controlled Substances Act. The "Fentanyl and Heroin Inter-Agency Task Force" will be established by the Attorney General to coordinate efforts in targeting organizations trafficking fentanyl and heroin, identifying sources of production and distribution, and providing best practices to law enforcement agencies. The "Fentanyl and Heroin Inter-Agency Task Force" will provide operational and investigative support to target and dismantle organizations trafficking fentanyl and heroin. A semiannual report will be submitted to Congress detailing the status of trafficking within the United States and efforts to eradicate it. The "Fentanyl and Heroin Inter-Agency Task Force" aims to combat fentanyl and heroin trafficking by evaluating the efficacy of eradication efforts and providing recommendations for Congressional authorizations. The Task Force includes representatives from various Federal entities such as Customs and Border Protection, the Drug Enforcement Administration, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The Attorney General appoints the chairperson of the Task Force, with members serving until a new representative is appointed. Members do not receive additional pay for their service. Operating rules and procedures are established for the Task Force. The Task Force members have one vote each and can propose changes to operating rules with a majority vote. Recommendations require a majority vote, and six members constitute a quorum. The Task Force can appoint a director. The Task Force may appoint a director and up to 10 staff members, who will be subject to certain civil service laws. The director can also hire experts and consultants as needed. The Task Force may appoint a director and staff members, who can be detailed from federal agencies on a reimbursable basis. The Task Force has powers to hold hearings, take testimony, and obtain official data. The Task Force has the authority to obtain information from US departments, use the US mails, receive administrative support services, and have contract authority. The Task Force has contract authority to compensate agencies or persons for services. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2019 through 2024. Definitions for fentanyl and heroin are provided. Amendments are made to the Controlled Substances Act. The Fentanyl and Heroin Task Force, with a budget of $5,000,000 for fiscal years 2019 through 2024, has been established under Sec. 521. Amendments to the Controlled Substances Act are included.
